data.modifiable:
• Infection control: Respiratory infection was the trigger
  • Early treatment: Higher dose steroids at initial HSP diagnosis
  • Monitoring: Serial creatinine checks after HSP diagnosis
  • Antibiotic stewardship: Avoid nephrotoxic agents
data.nonModifiable:
• Age >60: Higher risk of renal involvement
  • Male sex: Worse renal outcomes in adults
  • Underlying CKD: Even mild baseline impairment
  • HBV status: Complicates treatment options
data.geriatricRisk:
• Polypharmacy: 8+ medications at baseline
  • Frailty: Chronic respiratory disease
  • Reduced renal reserve: Age-related nephron loss
  • Atypical presentations: Less classic purpura distribution
  • Immunosenescence: Altered immune response

data.teachingPoints:
1

HSP in Elderly = Higher Risk

Adult HSP (>65y) → ↑ renal involvement, ↓ prognosis. Screen aggressively!

2

Microhematuria = NEVER Benign

In vasculitis, microhematuria warns of RPGN. Early nephro + Cr monitoring.

3

The Dissociation Sign

CRP ↓ but Cr ↑ → autoimmune process. Reconsider the diagnosis!

4

Screen HBV Before Steroids

Check HBsAg, Anti-HBc, Anti-HBs in ALL patients. Reactivation = fatal.

5

IgA ↑ + ANCA ⊖ = HSP

Elevated IgA + negative ANCA/ANA/GBM = IgA Vasculitis (not GPA/MPA).

data.leftColumn:

Mesangial onlyExcellent

data.rightColumn:
Biopsy Will Show

  • % glomeruli with crescents

  • IgA deposition pattern
  • Tubular/interstitial damage
Best: Active crescents, minimal fibrosis
Worst: >50% crescents + fibrosis

data.message1:
RECOGNIZE THE PATTERN
Purpura + AKI + active sediment = HSP Nephritis, not just UTI!
data.message2:
ACT ON WARNING SIGNS
Microhematuria at HSP dx → early nephro referral
data.message3:
THE DISSOCIATION SIGN
CRP ↓ but Cr ↑ = Autoimmune process. Pivot!
data.message4:
SCREEN BEFORE STEROIDS
Check HBV status → Entecavir first in HBsAg+ patients
data.bottomLine: Infection can trigger devastating autoimmune cascade. RPGN + HBV = complex therapeutic challenge requiring meticulous risk-benefit analysis.
